revision.text:
[[File:Agumbe Rainforest Research Station.jpg|thumb|220px|Agumbe Rainforest Research Station]] '''The Agumbe Rainforest Research Station''' (ARRS) is a field based conservation and research organisation situated inside the Agumbe Reserved Forest at [[Agumbe]] in the central [[Western Ghats]] of southern India. The Agumbe Reserved Forests receives an annual rainfall in excess of {{convert|7000|mm|abbr=on}} and is at an elevation of about {{convert|640|m|abbr=on}} above sea level.<ref name="Five wettest places in India you should know about">{{cite news|title=Five wettest places in India you should know about|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/education/story/five-wettest-places-in-india/1/445735.html|accessdate=17 July 2015|publisher=india today|date=June 19, 2015}}</ref> It forms a part of the Malnad-Kodagu corridor, which also includes the [[Someshwara Wildlife Sanctuary|Someshwara]], [[Mookambika Wildlife Sanctuary|Mookambika]], [[Bhadra Wildlife Sanctuary|Bhadra]], and [[Sharavati Wildlife Sanctuary|Sharavati]] Wildlife Sanctuaries, [[Kudremukh National Park]], and various other forest tracts and reserve forests around Kundapur, Shankaranarayana, Hosanagara, Sringeri, and Thirthahalli.<ref name="arrs_facts"> {{Cite web|url=http://www.agumberainforest.com/fast_facts.html |title=Fast Facts |work=agumberainforest.com |publisher=Agumbe Rainforest Research Station |accessdate=25 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111028015734/http://www.agumberainforest.com/fast_facts.html |archivedate=28 October 2011 }}</ref>
==History== [[Image:Kalinga mane.JPG|thumb|right|Kalinga Mane at ARRS. It was the first building at ARRS. Others were later added]] ARRS was founded in 2005, by leading Indian herpetologist [[Romulus Whitaker]]. Whitaker saw his very first [[king cobra]] (Ophiophagus hannah) here in 1971. He was also extremely taken by the reverence the people in the region showed for snakes, which was a major factor that drove him to establish a research station in Agumbe (Karnataka ).<ref name="arrs_about">{{Cite web|url=http://www.agumberainforest.com/about_us.html |title=About Us |work=agumberainforest.com |publisher=Agumbe Rainforest Research Station |accessdate=25 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140207235406/http://www.agumberainforest.com/about_us.html |archivedate=7 February 2014 }}</ref> The land is a revenue land was legally procured, the construction and activities are eco friendly and pose no disturbance to the wildlife.
[[Image:Agumbe Rain Forest Research Station.JPG|thumb|left|The cottages at ARRS for volunteers and researchers]]
==Activities== ARRS managed the world’s first radio-telemetry project on the King Cobra (Ophiophagus hannah), which is also the first radio-telemetry study done on any snake in India. Insight gained from this ecological study is being put into practice into king cobra management in the region. ARRS researchers have witnessed various unique behaviors among the species including a male king cobra killing a possibly pregnant female, a rare behavior even among mammals.
ARRS conducts and facilitates a wide variety of research projects, ranging from rainforest ecology, behavioral and population ecology, phenology, geoinformatics and socio economics.
Apart from research, ARRS focuses on education and outreach in the local community, schools and colleges. A well-developed volunteer and research intern programme makes the research station an ideal location for those interested in field based research and conservation The research station encourages and provides facilities for graduate and PHD students to conduct projects.
==See also== * [[Madras Crocodile Bank Trust]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Agumbe Rainforest Research Station}}
{{Coord|13.5181141|75.0888169|type:landmark_scale:1000|display=title}}

revision.text:
In [[general relativity]], the '''Bonnor beam''' is an [[Exact solutions in general relativity|exact solution]] which models an infinitely long, straight beam of [[light]]. It is an explicit example of a [[pp-wave spacetime]]. It is named after [[William B. Bonnor]] who first described it.
The Bonnor beam is obtained by matching together two regions:
* a uniform plane wave interior region, which is shaped like the [[world tube]] of a solid cylinder, and models the electromagnetic and gravitational fields inside the beam, * a vacuum exterior region, which models the gravitational field outside the beam.
On the "cylinder" where they meet, the two regions are required to obey matching conditions stating that the [[metric tensor]] and [[extrinsic curvature]] tensor must agree.
The interior part of the solution is defined by
:<math> \left\{ \begin{array}{lr} ds^2 = -8 \pi m r^2 \, du^2 - 2 \, du \, dv + dr^2 + r^2 \, d\theta^2,\\-\infty < u,\\ v < \infty,\\ 0 < r < r_0,\\ -\pi < \theta < \pi.\\ \end{array} \right.</math>
This is a [[null dust solution]] and can be interpreted as incoherent [[electromagnetic radiation]].
The exterior part of the solution is defined by
:<math> \left\{ \begin{array}{lr} ds^2 = -8 \pi m r_0^2 \left( 1 + 2 \log(r/r_0) \right) \, du^2 - 2 \, du \, dv + dr^2 + r^2 \, d\theta^2 \\ -\infty < u,\\ v < \infty,\\ r_0 < r < \infty,\\ -\pi < \theta < \pi.\\ \end{array} \right. </math>
The Bonnor beam can be generalized to several parallel beams travelling in the same direction. Perhaps surprisingly, the beams do not curve toward one another. On the other hand, "anti-parallel" beams (travelling along parallel trajectories, but in opposite directions) ''do'' attract each other. This reflects a general phenomenon: two pp-waves with parallel [[wave vector]]s superimpose linearly, but pp-waves with nonparallel wave vectors (including antiparallel Bonnor beams) do ''not'' superimpose linearly, as we would expect from the [[nonlinear]] nature of the [[Einstein field equation]].
==References==
* {{cite journal |author1=Faraoni, V. |author2=Dumse, R. M. |lastauthoramp=yes | title=The gravitational interaction of light: from weak to strong fields | journal=Gen. Rel. Grav. | year=1999 | volume=31 | issue= 1 | pages=91–105 | doi=10.1023/A:1018867405133|arxiv = gr-qc/9811052 |bibcode = 1999GReGr..31...91F }}. See also {{cite journal | title= The gravitational interaction of light: from weak to strong fields | arxiv=gr-qc/9811052 | author1= Faraoni | author2= Dumse | year= 1999 | doi=10.1023/A:1018867405133 | volume=31 | issue=1 | journal=General Relativity and Gravitation | pages=91–105|bibcode = 1999GReGr..31...91F }} * {{cite journal | author=Bonnor, W. B. | title=The gravitational field of light | journal=Comm. Math. Phys. | year=1969 | volume=13 | issue=3 | pages=163–174 | doi=10.1007/BF01645484|bibcode = 1969CMaPh..13..163B }}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bonnor Beam}} [[Category:Exact solutions in general relativity]]
{{physics-stub}}

revision.text:
{{about|the robotic arm on the [[Space Shuttle]]|the robotic arm on the [[International Space Station]]|Mobile Servicing System}} [[File:Canadarm 1 - STS-72.jpg|thumb|300 px|right|Canadarm (right) during Space Shuttle mission [[STS-72]].]] The '''Shuttle Remote Manipulator System''' ('''SRMS'''), also known as '''Canadarm''' ('''Canadarm 1'''), is a series of [[robotic arm]]s that were used on the [[Space Shuttle]] orbiters to deploy, maneuver and capture [[payload]]s. After the [[Space Shuttle Columbia disaster|Space Shuttle ''Columbia'' disaster]], the Canadarm was always paired with the [[Orbiter Boom Sensor System]] (OBSS), which was used to inspect the exterior of the Shuttle for damage to the [[Space Shuttle thermal protection system|thermal protection system]].
==Development== In 1969, the Canadarm was invited by the [[NASA|National Aeronautics and Space Administration]] (NASA) to participate in the [[Space Shuttle program]].<ref name="25Years">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YzVPAAAAMAAJ|title=A Heritage of Excellence: 25 years at Spar Aerospace Limited|last=Dotto|first=Lydia|date=1992|publisher=Spar Aerospace Limited|others=David Steel|isbn=0-9696618-0-0|location=Canada|pages=41–42|quote=[Frank] Mee is the inventor of the Canadarm hand, technically known as the "end effector.}}</ref> At the time what that participation would entail had not yet been decided but a manipulator system was identified as an important component.<ref name=25Years /> Canadian company [[Dilworth Secord and Meagher|DSMA]] ATCON had developed a robot to load fuel into [[CANDU reactor|CANDU nuclear reactors]]; this robot attracted NASA's attention.<ref name=25Years /> In 1975, NASA and the [[National Research Council (Canada)|Canadian National Research Council]] (NRC) signed a memorandum of understanding that Canada would develop and construct the Shuttle Remote Manipulator System.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CqI6waJAUnEC&source=gbs_navlinks_s|title=Browsing Science Research at the Federal Level in Canada: History, Research Activities and Publications|last=Wilks|first=Brian|date=2004|publisher=University of Toronto Press|pages=117|access-date=22 November 2013}}</ref>
NRC awarded the manipulator contract to [[Spar Aerospace]].<ref name="UofAEngMag" /> Three systems were constructed within this design, development, test and evaluation contract: an engineering model to assist in the design and testing of the Canadarm, a qualification model that was subjected to environmental testing to qualify the design for use in space, and a flight unit. Anthony "Tony" Zubrzycki, a design engineer at DSMA ATCON,<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Make The Wind Blow|last=Melbourne|first=James V.|publisher=Heirloom Publishing Inc.|year=2001|isbn=0-9694247-8-7|location=|pages=62–77}}</ref> while seconded to SPAR, originated the concept for the Canadarm End Effector, inspired by an elastic band around his fingers.<ref name=":0" /> Tony formally presented this concept to NASA officials.<ref name=":0" /> Frank Mee, head of the SPAR mechanical development laboratory, built the end effector prototype<!--At his home, he fabricated a small model made out of cardboard and string; and brought it to work.<ref name=25Years />--> based on Tony's concept and is credited by SPAR<ref name=":0" /> as the inventor of the Canadarm End Effector. The three-wire crossover design won over the claw-like mechanisms and others, such as the camera iris model,<ref name=":0" /> that were being considered.
The main controls algorithms were developed by SPAR and by subcontractor [[Dynacon]] Inc. of [[Toronto]]. [[CAE Inc.|CAE Electronics]] Ltd. in [[Montreal]] provided the display and control panel and the hand controllers located in the Shuttle aft flight deck. Other electronic interfaces, servoamplifiers and power conditioners located on the Canadarm were designed and built by SPAR at its Montreal factory. The graphite composite boom that provides the structural connection between the shoulder and the elbow joint and the similar boom that connects the elbow to the wrist were produced by General Dynamics in the United States. Dilworth, Secord, Meagher and Associates, Ltd. in Toronto was contracted to produce the engineering model end effector then SPAR evolved the design and produced the qualification and flight units.The shuttle flight software that monitors and controls the Canadarm was developed in Houston, Texas, by the Federal Systems Division of [[IBM]]. Rockwell International's Space Transportation Systems Division designed, developed, tested and built the systems used to attach the Canadarm to the payload bay of the orbiter.
An acceptance ceremony for NASA was held at Spar's RMS Division in Toronto on the 11th of February 1981.<ref name=25Years /> Here [[Larkin Kerwin]], then the head of the NRC, gave the SRMS the informal name, Canadarm.<ref name=25Years />
The first remote manipulator system was delivered to NASA in April 1981.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ieee.ca/millennium/canadarm/canadarm_technical.html|title=The Shuttle Remote Manipulator System — The Canadarm|publisher=IEEE Canada|access-date=22 November 2013}}</ref> Astronaut [[Judith Resnik]] developed the NASA [[software]] and onboard operating procedures for the system.<ref>''Engineering Women: Re-visioning Women's Scientific Achievements and Impacts'', By Jill S. Tietjen, Springer 2016, page 72</ref> In all, five arms—Nos. 201, 202, 301, 302, and 303—were built and delivered to NASA. Arm 302 was lost in the ''Challenger'' accident.<ref name="canadarm">{{cite web | url=http://www.asc-csa.gc.ca/eng/canadarm/flight.asp | publisher=Canada Space Agency | title= Flight History of Canadarm | date=28 October 2011 | access-date=27 October 2012}}</ref>
==Design and capabilities== [[File:Hubble First Servicing EVA - GPN-2000-001085.jpg|left|thumb|[[F. Story Musgrave]], anchored on the end of the Canadarm, prepares to be elevated to the top of the [[Hubble Space Telescope]] during [[STS-61]].]] The original Canadarm was capable of deploying and retrieving payloads [[mass|weighing]] up to {{convert|332.5|kg|abbr=on}} in space. In the mid-1990s the arm control system was redesigned to increase the payload capability to {{convert|3293|kg|abbr=on}} in order to support space station assembly operations. While able to maneuver payloads with the mass of a loaded bus in space, the arm motors cannot lift the arm's own weight when on the ground.<ref name="UofAEngMag" /> NASA therefore developed a model of the arm for use at its training facility within the Johnson Space Center located in Houston, Texas. The Canadarm can also retrieve, repair and deploy satellites, provide a mobile extension ladder for extravehicular activity crew members for work stations or foot restraints, and be used as an inspection aid to allow the flight crew members to view the orbiter's or payload's surfaces through a television camera on the Canadarm.
The basic Canadarm configuration consists of a manipulator arm, a Canadarm display and control panel, including rotational and translational hand controllers at the orbiter aft flight deck flight crew station, and a manipulator controller interface unit that interfaces with the orbiter computer. Most of the time, the arm operators see what they are doing by looking at the [[Advanced Space Vision System]] screen next to the controllers. [[File:Canadarm 1 End Effector.jpg|thumb|The Canadarm 1 End Effector.]] One crew member operates the Canadarm from the aft flight deck control station, and a second crew member usually assists with television camera operations. This allows the Canadarm operator to view Canadarm operations through the aft flight deck payload and overhead windows and through the closed-circuit television monitors at the aft flight deck station.
The Canadarm is outfitted with an explosive-based mechanism to allow the arm to be jettisoned. This safety system allows the Orbiter's payload bay doors to be closed in the event that the arm fails in an extended position and is not able to be retracted.<ref name=UofAEngMag>{{cite news|author=Garry Lindberg|title=Canadarm and its U of A Connections|url=http://www.uofaweb.ualberta.ca/uofaengineer/article.cfm?article=28369&issue=28299|work=U of A Engineer Magazine|publisher=University of Alberta|access-date=7 December 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041129001731/http://www.uofaweb.ualberta.ca/uofaengineer/article.cfm?article=28369&issue=28299|archivedate=29 November 2004|df=}}</ref>
The Canadarm is {{convert|15.2|m|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|38|cm|abbr=on}} diameter with six [[Degrees of freedom (mechanics)|degrees of freedom]]. It weighs {{convert|410|kg|abbr=on}} by itself, and {{convert|450|kg|abbr=on}} as part of the total system. The Canadarm has six joints that correspond roughly to the joints of the human arm, with shoulder yaw and pitch joints, an elbow pitch joint, and wrist pitch, yaw, and roll joints. The [[Robot end effector|end effector]] is the unit at the end of the wrist that grapples the payload's [[grapple fixture]]. The two lightweight boom segments are called the upper and lower arms. The upper boom connects the shoulder and elbow joints, and the lower boom connects the elbow and wrist joints.
==Service history== [[File:Wisoff on the Arm - GPN-2000-001069.jpg|thumb|Astronaut on the end of the arm, 1993.]] [[File:STS-116 - P5 Truss hand-off to ISS (NASA S116-E-05765).jpg|thumb|315px|right|The Canadarm2 moves toward a P5 truss section, being held by ''Discovery''{{'}}s Canadarm, in preparation for a hand-off during [[STS-116]].]] A simulated Canadarm installed on the [[Space Shuttle Enterprise|Space Shuttle ''Enterprise'']] was seen when the prototype orbiter's payload bay doors were open to test hangar facilities early in the shuttle program.<ref>{{cite news | first=Justin |last=Ray | url=http://spaceflightnow.com/delta/d352/omcf/ | title=Vandenberg's space shuttle hangar | date=5 January 2011 | work=Space Flight Now | access-date=27 October 2012}}</ref> The Canadarm was first tested in orbit in 1981, on [[Space Shuttle Columbia|Space Shuttle ''Columbia''{{'}}s]] [[STS-2]] mission. Its first operational use was on [[STS-3]] to deploy and maneuver the Plasma Diagnostics Package.<ref name="canadarm" /> Canadarm has since flown on more than 90 missions with all five orbiters.
Since the installation of the [[Mobile Servicing System#Canadarm2|Canadarm2]] on the [[International Space Station]] (ISS), the two arms have been used to hand over segments of the station for assembly from the Canadarm to the Canadarm2; the use of both elements in tandem has earned the nickname of "Canadian Handshake" in the media.
===Retirement=== The Canadarm's 90th and final shuttle mission was in July 2011 on [[STS-135]], delivering the [[Raffaello MPLM|Raffaello]] [[Multi-Purpose Logistics Module|MPLM]] to the ISS and back. ''Discovery's'' Canadarm is displayed next to her in the [[National Air and Space Museum]].<ref name=chrisg>{{cite news | author=Chris Gebhardt | url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2010/11/discoverys-retirement-provide-insight-fate-fleets-robotic-arms/ | title=Discovery's retirement plans provide insight into the fate of the robotic arm | date=17 November 2010 | publisher=NASA | access-date=27 October 2012}}</ref> ''Endeavour'' left its OBSS at the International Space Station as part of its [[STS-134|final mission]], while its Canadarm was originally going to be displayed in the headquarters of the [[Canadian Space Agency]].<ref name=chrisg /><ref>{{cite news | author=Roland Kiehne | url=http://www.montrealgazette.com/Letter+Canadarm+should+easy+visit/7002778/story.html | title=Letter: Canadarm should be easy to visit | date=27 July 2012 | work=The Montreal Gazette | access-date=27 October 2012 }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> However, ''Endeavour''{{'}}s Canadarm is now on permanent display at the [[Canada Aviation and Space Museum]] in [[Ottawa]].<ref>{{cite news | author=Andy Johnson | url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/sci-tech/unveiling-exhibit-hadfield-sends-first-canadarm-last-command-from-space-1.1263958 | title=Unveiling exhibit, Hadfield sends first Canadarm 'last command' from space | date=2 May 2013 | work=CTV News | access-date=2 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | author=Elizabeth Howell | url=http://www.space.com/20949-space-shuttle-canadarm-museum-exhibit.html | title=Space Shuttle's Robotic Arm Goes on Display at Canadian Museum | date=2 May 2013 | work=Space.com | access-date=2 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | author=Canadian Space Agency | url=http://www.asc-csa.gc.ca/eng/media/news_releases/2013/0502.asp | title=Minister Moore Unveils Exhibit for Canada's National Space Icon: the Canadarm | date=2 May 2013 | work=Canadian Space Agency | access-date=1 July 2013 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130506062113/http://www.asc-csa.gc.ca/eng/media/news_releases/2013/0502.asp | archivedate=6 May 2013 | df= }}</ref> The last of the Canadarms to fly in space, the SRMS flown aboard ''Atlantis'' on the final space shuttle mission, STS-135 in July 2011, was shipped to NASA's Johnson Space Center in Houston for engineering study and possible reuse on a future mission.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.collectspace.com/news/news-050213a.html | title=Canadarm on display: Space shuttle robot arm unveiled at Canadian museum | date=2 May 2013}}</ref>
== Derivative == Based on the Canadarm1, the larger [[Mobile Servicing System#Canadarm2|Canadarm2]] is used for berthing the trusses, the commercial vehicles and inspecting the whole ISS, and the smaller Canadarm3 will be used for berthing the commercial vehicles and inspecting the whole [[Deep Space Gateway]].
== Future Use == This Canadarm1 will be used for berthing the modules and inspecting the whole [[Exploration Gateway Platform]].
==In popular media== *On November 13, 2012, Google Canada displayed a doodle on its home search page to celebrate the 31st anniversary of the Canadarm's first use in space.<ref name=googdood>{{cite news | url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/story/2012/11/13/tec-google-doodle-canadarm31.html | title=Google doodle honours Canadarm at 31 | date=13 November 2012 | work=CBC News | access-date=13 November 2012}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Robotics}} *[[Mobile Servicing System]] (MSS), also known by its primary component the Canadarm2, used on the ISS *[[European Robotic Arm]], a fourth robotic arm to be installed on the ISS built in the [[Netherlands]] by [[Airbus|EADS]] *The [[Kibo (ISS module)#Remote Manipulator System|Japanese Experiment Module Remote Manipulator System]] (JEMRMS), used on the ISS module [[Kibo (ISS module)|Kibo]] is a Japanese-built robotic arm system *[[Dextre]], also known as the Special Purpose Dexterous Manipulator (SPDM), used on the ISS and built by MDA *[[Strela (crane)|Strela]], a [[Russia]]n-built crane used on the ISS to perform similar tasks as the Mobile Servicing System
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Canadarm}} * http://science.ksc.nasa.gov/shuttle/technology/sts-newsref/sts-caws.html#sts-deploy * http://www.asc-csa.gc.ca/eng/canadarm/default.asp * [http://www.cbc.ca/archives/categories/science-technology/technology/canadarm-a-technology-star/topic-canadarm---a-technology-star.html CBC Digital Archives - Canadarm - A Technology Star]

revision.text:
{{More citations needed|date=June 2008}} During the [[Space Shuttle program]], several missions were canceled. Many were canceled as a result of the [[Challenger disaster|''Challenger'']] and the [[Columbia disaster|''Columbia'']] disasters. Many early missions were canceled due to delays in the development of the shuttle. Others were canceled because of changes in payload and missions requirements. {{TOC limit|limit=2}} == Canceled due to the late development of the shuttle == In 1972, [[NASA]]'s planners had projected for 570 shuttle missions between 1980 and 1991.Turnill, p.73 Later, this estimate was lowered to 487 launches between 1980 and 1992.Turnill, inner cover The details of the first 23 projected missions, listed in the third edition of ''Manned Spaceflight'' ([[Reginald Turnill]], 1978) and the first edition of the ''STS Flight Assignment Baseline'', an internal NASA document published in October 1977,{{cite web |url=https://www.wired.com/wiredscience/2012/03/what-shuttle-should-have-been-the-october-1977-flight-manifest/ |title=What Shuttle Should Have Been: The October 1977 Flight Manifest |publisher=Wired |date= |accessdate=5 November 2012}} are presented below. {|class="sortable wikitable" ! scope="col" width="60"|Mission ! scope="col" width="125"|Original
launch date(s) ! scope="col" | Shuttle ! scope="col" | Landing site ! scope="col" class="unsortable" |Mission details |- ! scope="row" | STS-1A
OFT-1 | June 1979 | [[Space Shuttle Columbia|''Columbia'']] | [[Edwards Air Force Base|Edwards]] | Originally scheduled as the first orbital test. The crew was to consist of a commander and pilot, and the test flight was to last 2 days and 5 hours. No crew was named at the initial announcement of the mission, but [[John Young (astronaut)|John Young]] and [[Robert L. Crippen|Robert Crippen]] were officially announced as the STS-1 crew in March 1978, when the shuttle was still originally scheduled for a 1979 launch.{{cite web |title=STS-1 - First Space Shuttle Mission Press Kit |url=http://www.jsc.nasa.gov/history/shuttle_pk/pk/Flight_001_STS-001_Press_Kit.pdf |publisher=Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center |accessdate=6 November 2012 |page=46 |year=1981}} |- ! scope="row" | STS-2A
OFT-2 | July 1979
6 March 1980 | [[Space Shuttle Columbia|''Columbia'']] | [[Edwards Air Force Base|Edwards]] | Originally scheduled as the second orbital flight test. The 5-day mission was to see the crew of [[Fred Haise]] and [[Jack R. Lousma|Jack Lousma]] take the [[Teleoperator Retrieval System]] to the [[Skylab]] space station in order to boost it into a higher orbit.{{cite web |url=http://www.astronautix.com/flights/sts2a.htm |title=STS-2A |publisher=Encyclopedia Astronautica |date= |accessdate=31 March 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100108023229/http://astronautix.com/flights/sts2a.htm |archivedate=8 January 2010 |df=}} [[Vance D. Brand]] and [[C. Gordon Fullerton]] were their backups.{{cite news |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dw7Vu20g1cEC&lpg=PA350|title=Skylab brings NASA down to Earth |work=New Scientist |date=11 May 1978|author=Lewis, Richard S. |page=350}} By April 1979, when it was understood that the Shuttle could not be launched in time to rendezvous with Skylab, STS-2 was rescheduled for a 6 March 1980 launch, carrying the OSTA-1 payload and the [[Remote Manipulator System|RMS]] for the first time.{{cite web |title=STS-2 Conceptual Flight Profile |url=https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/19790077390_1979077390.pdf |publisher=NASA Mission Planning and Analysis Division |accessdate=6 November 2012 |year=1979}} This re-manifested [[STS-2]] finally launched on 12 November 1981, with [[Joe Engle]] and [[Richard Truly]] in place of Haise and Lousma, respectively. |- ! scope="row" | STS-3
OFT-3 | September 1979 | [[Space Shuttle Columbia|''Columbia'']] | [[Edwards Air Force Base|Edwards]] | Originally scheduled as the third orbital flight test. The 7-day mission was to see the two-man crew (commander and pilot) test shuttle maneuvering and remote manipulator systems. |- ! scope="row" | STS-4
OFT-4 | December 1979 | [[Space Shuttle Columbia|''Columbia'']] | [[Edwards Air Force Base|Edwards]] | Originally scheduled as the fourth orbital flight test. The crew was to consist of a commander and pilot, and the mission was to last seven days. |- ! scope="row" | STS-5
OFT-5 | February 1980 | [[Space Shuttle Columbia|''Columbia'']] | [[Kennedy Space Center|Kennedy]] | Originally scheduled as the fifth orbital flight test. The crew was to consist of commander [[Ken Mattingly]], pilot [[Henry Hartsfield]] and one or two mission specialists.{{cite book |last=Evans |first=Ben |title=Space Shuttle Columbia: Her Missions and Crews |year=2005 |publisher=Praxis Publishing |isbn=0-387-21517-4 |page=48}} The mission was to last 7 days. First landing at [[Kennedy Space Center]]. |- ! scope="row" | STS-6
OFT-6 | March 1980 | [[Space Shuttle Columbia|''Columbia'']] | [[Edwards Air Force Base|Edwards]] | Originally scheduled as the sixth orbital flight test. The crew of four were to conduct first test of operational payloads and conduct the first EVA from the shuttle. The mission was to last seven days. |- ! scope="row" | STS-7 | 30 May 1980
27 February 1981 | [[Space Shuttle Columbia|''Columbia'']] | [[Kennedy Space Center|Kennedy]] | First operational flight. The crew of three were to place the [[LDEF]] satellite into orbit and the mission was to last five days. The LDEF was eventually released in 1984 from ''[[Space Shuttle Challenger|Challenger]]'' during [[STS-41-C]]. By 1979, when it became clear that the original launch schedule could not be kept to, STS-7 was re-manifested with the [[TDRS-1|TDRS-A]] satellite and scheduled to launch on 27 February 1981 with a crew of four and a duration of two days. This rescheduled STS-7 would also have landed at [[Kennedy Space Center]].{{cite web |title=STS-7 Flight Feasibility Assessment |url=https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/19800019905_1980019905.pdf |publisher=NASA Flight Planning Branch |accessdate=5 November 2012 |year=1979}} |- ! scope="row" | STS-8 | 1 July 1980 | [[Space Shuttle Columbia|''Columbia'']] | [[Edwards Air Force Base|Edwards]] | The crew of three were to place the satellites [[TDRS-1|TDRS-A]] and [[Satellite Business Systems|SBS-A]] into orbit during the 2-day mission. TDRS-A was sent into orbit on ''Challenger's'' maiden flight, [[STS-6]], in April 1983. |- ! scope="row" | STS-9 | 1 August 1980 | [[Space Shuttle Columbia|''Columbia'']] | [[Edwards Air Force Base|Edwards]] | The crew of three were to place the satellites [[GOES 4]] and [[Anik (satellite)|Anik]]-C1 into orbit during the 3-day mission. GOES 4 was launched atop a [[Delta 3000|Delta 3914]] a month after its originally scheduled launch on the shuttle. After this mission, ''Columbia'' would be returned to the Rockwell plant at Palmdale for removal of the ejection seats and test instrumentation and would receive higher capacity fuel cells, all in preparation for the first Spacelab mission. |- ! scope="row" | STS-10 | 14 November 1980 | [[Space Shuttle Columbia|''Columbia'']] | [[Edwards Air Force Base|Edwards]] | Originally scheduled for launch on 1980. The crew of three were to place the satellites [[TDRS-B]] and [[Satellite Business Systems|SBS-B]] into orbit during the 3-day mission. TDRS-B was rescheduled for STS-51-E but became re-manifested on [[STS-51-L]], where it was [[Space Shuttle Challenger disaster|destroyed along with ''Challenger'']] on 28 January 1986. |- ! scope="row" | STS-11 | 18 December 1980 | [[Space Shuttle Columbia|''Columbia'']] | [[Edwards Air Force Base|Edwards]] | Scheduled to carry the European [[Spacelab]]-1 science module. The crew of five were to consist of three NASA astronauts and two European payload specialists. The mission was to last seven days. This first Spacelab mission was later launched as [[STS-9]] in November 1983. |- ! scope="row" | STS-12 | 30 January 1981 | [[Space Shuttle Columbia|''Columbia'']] | [[Edwards Air Force Base|Edwards]] | The crew of three were to place the satellites [[TDRS-3|TDRS-C]] and [[Anik (satellite)|Anik]]-C2 into orbit during the 2-day mission. An alternate mission was also planned which replaced the TDRS-C with an [[Intelsat]]-V satellite, and would last five days instead of two. TDRS-C was eventually made as the replacement for the destroyed TDRS-B and launched from ''[[Space Shuttle Discovery|Discovery]]'' on [[STS-26]] in September 1988. |- ! scope="row" | STS-13 | 3 March 1981 | [[Space Shuttle Columbia|''Columbia'']] | [[Edwards Air Force Base|Edwards]] | The crew of three were to place the [[GOES 5|GOES-E]] satellite into orbit during the 5-day mission. GOES-E was eventually launched on a [[Delta 3000|Delta 3914]] over two months after its originally scheduled launch on the shuttle. |- ! scope="row" | STS-14 | 7 April 1981 | [[Space Shuttle Columbia|''Columbia'']] | [[Edwards Air Force Base|Edwards]] | Scheduled to carry four Spacelab instrumentation pallets and a pressurized "igloo" used to support the payloads. The crew of five was to consist of two payload specialists. The mission was to last 12 days. |- ! scope="row" | STS-15 | 13 May 1981 | [[Space Shuttle Columbia|''Columbia'']] | [[Edwards Air Force Base|Edwards]] | During this mission, the satellites [[TDRS-4|TDRS-D]] and [[Satellite Business Systems|SBS-C]] would be placed into orbit. The Anik-C3 satellite could be substituted in place of SBS-C. TDRS-D was launched from ''Discovery'' on [[STS-29]] in March 1989, with SBS-C being launched on ''Columbia's'' first operational mission, [[STS-5]], in November 1982. |- ! scope="row" | STS-16 | 16 June 1981 | [[Space Shuttle Columbia|''Columbia'']] | [[Edwards Air Force Base|Edwards]] | Originally scheduled for launch on 16 June 1981, carrying the [[Spacelab]]-3 science module. A "payload of opportunity" of 9 tons (8.16 mt) also existed, which could accommodate a communications satellite. The crew of five was to consist of two payload specialists. |- ! scope="row" | STS-17 | 16 July 1981 | [[Space Shuttle Enterprise|''Enterprise'']] | [[Edwards Air Force Base|Edwards]] | Originally to be the first spaceflight of the shuttle ''[[Space Shuttle Enterprise|Enterprise]]''. It was to place an [[Intelsat]] V satellite into orbit and retrieve the LDEF. ''Enterprise'' never flew in space, and instead its place as the second shuttle in the fleet was taken by ''Challenger''. |- ! scope="row" | STS-18 | 29 July 1981 | [[Space Shuttle Columbia|''Columbia'']] | [[Edwards Air Force Base|Edwards]] | Scheduled to carry a [[Spacelab]] pallet and pressurized "igloo". A tentative planned payload would be flown for the [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]], which would make it the first such payload flown on the Shuttle. |- ! scope="row" | STS-19 | 2 September 1981 | [[Space Shuttle Columbia|''Columbia'']] | [[Edwards Air Force Base|Edwards]] | Was to carry a series of five [[Spacelab]] pallets. |- ! scope="row" | STS-20 | 30 September 1981 | [[Space Shuttle Enterprise|''Enterprise'']] | [[Edwards Air Force Base|Edwards]] | Originally scheduled for launch on 30 September 1981, carrying the [[Spacelab]]-4 life-science module and an unpressurized Spacelab pallet. |- ! scope="row" | STS-21 | 14 October 1981 | [[Space Shuttle Columbia|''Columbia'']] | [[Edwards Air Force Base|Edwards]] | A crew of three was to retrieve the [[Solar Maximum Mission]] satellite and bring it back to Earth after a five-day mission. ''Columbia'' would have carried an "OMS Kit" which contained additional fuel for the shuttle's [[Orbital Maneuvering System]], necessary to safely reach the SMM's orbit. The SMM, launched in February 1980, was eventually retrieved and repaired in orbit on [[STS-41-C]] in 1984, and continued operating until 1989. |- ! scope="row" | STS-22 | 25 November 1981 | [[Space Shuttle Enterprise|''Enterprise'']] | [[Edwards Air Force Base|Edwards]] | Was planned to carry an [[European Space Agency|ESA]]-operated [[Spacelab]] module and additional pallet. |- ! scope="row" | STS-23 | 5 January 1982 | [[Space Shuttle Columbia|''Columbia'']] | [[Edwards Air Force Base|Edwards]] | Was to launch the [[Galileo (spacecraft)|''Galileo'']] probe (then known as the "Jupiter Orbiter and Probe") to Jupiter using a modified [[Inertial Upper Stage|IUS]] booster. ''Galileo'' was eventually delivered to orbit by ''Atlantis'' during [[STS-34]], launched 18 October 1989, after lengthy delays. |} Later in the development process, NASA suggested using the first manned space shuttle mission, [[STS-1]], as a [[sub-orbital spaceflight|sub-orbital]] test of the [[Space Shuttle abort modes#Intact abort modes|Return to Landing Site (RTLS)]] flight profile devised for emergency abort scenarios.{{cite news |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080208195129/http://www.popularmechanics.com:80/science/air_space/1282596.html?page=4 |work=[[Popular Mechanics]] |title=Astronauts in Danger |first=Stefano |last=Coledan |date=December 2000}} ''Columbia'' would have launched from Kennedy Space Center, then executed a 180-degree turn at a speed of {{convert|8400|km/h|mph}}, or 6.7 times the [[speed of sound]], in order to land at the Kennedy Space Center runway. The mission was canceled when astronauts refused to fly it, having deemed the plan to be too dangerous. STS-1 commander [[John Young (astronaut)|John W. Young]] recalled that "I said no. I said let's not practice [[Russian roulette]], because you may have a loaded gun there. So we didn't." == Canceled between the first flight of the shuttle (1981) and the [[Space Shuttle Challenger disaster|''Challenger'' disaster]] (1986) == {|class="sortable wikitable" ! scope="col" width="60"|Mission ! scope="col" width="125"|Original

Payton]] (Payload Specialist) | Originally to be the first classified mission for the Department of Defense; canceled due to concerns with the payload's Inertial Upper Stage booster.{{cite book |last=Evans |first=Ben |title=Space Shuttle Challenger: Ten Journeys Into the Unknown |year=2007 |publisher=Praxis Publishing |isbn=0-387-46355-0 |page=95 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PpgG2NqNs_AC}} The entire crew, which had been assigned in October 1982, flew on [[STS-51-C]] in January 1985. |- ! scope="row" | STS-12 | March 1984 | ''[[Space Shuttle Discovery|Discovery]]'' | * [[Henry W. Resnik]] (Mission Specialist) | Originally to be the maiden flight of ''Discovery''. Its original mission was to deploy a [[TDRS]] satellite, which was canceled due to concerns with the [[Inertial Upper Stage]] (IUS) that was to be used in the mission. The crew (along with payload specialist [[Charles D. Walker]]) eventually flew on [[STS-41-D]] in August 1984. |- ! scope="row" | STS-41-E | July 1984 | ''[[Space Shuttle Challenger|Challenger]]'' | * [[Thomas K. Mattingly II]] (Commander) * [[Loren J. Hoffman]] (Mission Specialist) | Canceled after [[STS-41-D]] was delayed{{cite web |url=http://science.ksc.nasa.gov/shuttle/technology/sts-newsref/stsover-missions.html |title=Space Shuttle Mission Summaries |last=NASA |date=3 August 2000 |publisher=NASA |accessdate=23 November 2008}} due to its RSLS abort. Most of STS-41-F's payloads were added to the STS-41-D mission and eventually launched in August 1984. STS-41-F was scheduled to launch at 13:35 UTC on 29 August 1984, and land on Runway 17 at [[Edwards Air Force Base]] at 11:32 UTC on 4 September.{{citation needed|date=May 2013}} |- ! scope="row" | STS-51-E | March 1985 | ''[[Space Shuttle Challenger|Challenger]]'' | * [[Karol J. {{Infobox person | name = Darlene Cavalier | image = | caption = Darlene Cavalier – Recent Photo | residence = [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]], U.S. | occupation = Citizen science advocate, writer, editor | alma_mater = [[University of Pennsylvania]] }}
{{external media | width = 210px | align = right | headerimage= | video1 = [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NOmD5jMrlIM "We're here specifically to help inspire young women to consider careers in science, technology, engineering, math and health"], "Darlene Cavalier is The Science Cheerleader"}}
'''Darlene Cavalier''' is an advocate for public participation in science and science policy, a writer, and an entrepreneur.
She is a Professor of Practice at [[Arizona State University]], School for the Future of Innovation in Society and the Center for Engagement and Training in Science and Society.<ref>{{cite web|title=Darlene Cavalier|url=https://isearch.asu.edu/profile/2186378|website=iSearch|publisher=Arizona State University|accessdate=17 July 2017}}</ref> She is the founder of [[SciStarter]], an online citizen hotspot that connects people to [[citizen science]] projects around the world.
In 2016, Cavalier co-organized Citizen Science Maker Summit, hosted by ASU.<ref>{{cite web|title=ASU researchers bring citizen scientists into the fold to advance learning|url=https://asunow.asu.edu/20170706-asu-researchers-bring-citizen-scientists-fold-advance-learning|website=Got a Minute?|publisher=Arizona State University|accessdate=14 July 2017}}</ref> In 2017, Cavalier was appointed to the [[National Academy of Sciences]]' Committee on Designing Citizen Science to Support Science Learning to identify and describe existing citizen science projects that support science learning in both formal and informal settings.<ref>{{cite web|title=Committee Membership Information|url=https://www8.nationalacademies.org/cp/CommitteeView.aspx?key=49867|website=Current Projects System|publisher=National Academies|accessdate=14 July 2017}}</ref> The committee will develop a set of evidence-based principles to guide the design of citizen science.
Cavalier is also the co-founder of the Expert and Citizen Assessment of Science and Technology (ECAST) network<ref>{{cite web|title=Partners|url=https://ecastnetwork.org/network-partners/|website=ecastnetwork.org|publisher=Expert & Citizen Assessment of Science & Technology|accessdate=14 July 2017}}</ref>, co-editor of The Rightful Place of Science: Citizen Science,<ref>{{cite book|last1=Cavalier|first1=Darlene|last2=Kennedy|first2=Eric B.|title=The Rightful Place of Science: Citizen Science|date=May 29, 2016|publisher=Consortium for Science, Policy, & Outcomes|isbn=0692694838|url=https://www.amazon.com/Rightful-Place-Science-Citizen/dp/0692694838|accessdate=14 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Explore the Frontiers of Citizen Science in New Book from CSPO|url=http://cspo.org/news/rightful-place-of-science-citizen-science/|website=cspo.org|publisher=Consortium for Science, Policy, & Outcomes|accessdate=20 July 2017}}</ref> author of The Science of Cheerleading<ref>{{cite web|last1=Cavalier|first1=Darlene|title=The Science of Cheerleading|url=https://www.amazon.com/Rightful-Place-Science-Citizen/dp/0692694838|website=iTunes|publisher=Apple Inc.|accessdate=17 July 2017}}</ref>, a member of the [[Environmental Protection Agency]]’s National Advisory Council for Environmental Policy and Technology<ref>{{cite web|title=National Advisory Council for Environmental Policy and Technology: 2016-2018 Membership|url=https://www.epa.gov/faca/national-advisory-council-environmental-policy-and-technology-2016-2018-membership|website=epa.gov|publisher=U.S. Environmental Protection Agency|accessdate=14 July 2017}}</ref> and a founding member of the Citizen Science Association, a membership organization dedicated to the dissemination of scholarship related to designing and implementing citizen science.<ref>{{cite web|title=Board of Directors|url=http://citizenscience.org/association/about/board-of-directors/|website=citizenscience.org|publisher=Citizen Science Association|accessdate=14 July 2017}}</ref>
She is also the founder of Science Cheerleader, an organization of more than 300 current and former [[National Football League|NFL]] and [[National Basketball Association|NBA]] cheerleaders pursuing careers in science, technology, engineering and math. They playfully challenge stereotypes, inspire young women to consider [[Science, technology, engineering, and mathematics|STEM]] careers, and help people from all walks of life get involved in science. The organization plays on her former position as a cheerleader for the [[Philadelphia 76ers]] basketball team.<ref>Bob Grant, "Science, Rah Rah" The Scientist 2009-09-01 "[http://www.the-scientist.com/2009/09/1/22/1/]" Retrieved 2010-03-05.</ref> In 2013, the Science Cheerleaders partnered with the [[Pop Warner Little Scholars|Pop Warner]] organizations to lead the "world's largest cheerleading cheer," an event that was recognized by [[Guinness World Records]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Largest cheerleading cheer|url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/largest-cheerleading-cheer|website=Guinness World Records|publisher=Guinness World Records|accessdate=14 July 2017}}</ref> The Science Cheerleaders have been featured on [https://www.sciencecheerleader.com/category/in_the_news/ national and international media outlets] and serve as principal investigators in research projects including [http://spacemicrobes.org Project MERCCURI], a study of microbes on the International Space Station.<ref>{{cite web|title=Project MERCCURI|url=https://www.scientificamerican.com/citizen-science/project-merccuri/|website=Scientific American|publisher=Nature America Inc.|accessdate=20 July 2017}}</ref>
Cavalier earned a bachelor's degree from [[Temple University]] and a master's degree from the [[University of Pennsylvania]] where she studied the role of citizens in science. She is a Professor of Practice at [[Arizona State University]]'s Consortium for Science, Policy, & Outcomes, and the Center for Engagement and Training in Science and Society. She lives in Philadelphia with her husband and four children.
She is a senior advisor and contributor to [[Discover Magazine]].<ref>Darlene Cavalier, "Science Sets Its Eyes On The Prize" Discover Magazine 2009-12-25 "[http://discovermagazine.com/2010/jan-feb/069/]" Retrieved 2010-03-18.</ref><ref>Darlene Cavalier, "A Shad Situation" Discover Magazine 2009-05-17 "[http://discovermagazine.com/2009/jun/04-a-shad-situation]" Retrieved 2010-03-18.</ref><ref>Discover Magazine "Discoblog, "[http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/discoblog/author/dcavalier/]" Retrieved 2010-03-08.</ref> She served on the steering committee of [[Science Debate 2008]].
In addition to Discover, her writing has appeared in science publications such as the [[New York Academy of Sciences]] Magazine<ref>Darlene Cavalier & Alex Soojung-Kim Pang, "The Growth of Citizen Science" New York Academy of Sciences Magazine 2009-10-01 "[http://www.nyas.org/Publications/Detail.aspx?cid=5222b62e-4a1b-4fb2-bf6e-a38e263dee49]" Retrieved 2010-03-06.</ref> and [[Science Progress]] .<ref>Darlene Cavalier, "Harnessing Citizen Scientists" Science Progress 2008-07-07 "[http://www.scienceprogress.org/2008/07/harnessing-citizen-scientists/]" Retrieved 2010-03-06.</ref> Her work has been featured on the Today Show<ref>{{cite web|title=Heard it on Today|url=http://www.today.com/allday/heard-it-today-9-21-carol-burnett-show-moment-science-1B6028700|website=Today.com|publisher=National Broadcasting Company|accessdate=20 July 2017}}</ref>, CNN, Fox National Headline News, the Washington Post, Lab Out Loud,<ref>{{cite web|title=Citizen Science Day: Goggles, Lab Coat, Degree not Required|url=http://laboutloud.com/2017/05/episode-167-scistarter/|website=LabOutLoud.com|accessdate=20 July 2017}}</ref> and other media outlets.
==See also== [[New York Academy of Sciences]]

{{italic title}} '''''Euclides Danicus''''' (the Danish Euclid) is one of three books of mathematics written by [[Georg Mohr]].<ref>{{citation | last1 = Andersen | first1 = Kirsti | last2 = Meyer | first2 = Henrik | doi = 10.1111/j.1600-0498.1985.tb00833.x | issue = 2 | journal = Centaurus | mr = 825846 | pages = 139–144 | title = Georg Mohr's three books and the ''Gegenübung auf Compendium Euclidis Curiosi'' | volume = 28 | year = 1985}}.</ref> It was published in 1672 simultaneously in [[Copenhagen]] and [[Amsterdam]], in [[Danish language|Danish]] and [[Dutch language|Dutch]] respectively. It contains the first proof of the [[Mohr–Mascheroni theorem]], which states that every geometric construction that can be performed using a [[compass and straightedge]] can also be done with compass alone.<ref name="gla">{{citation | last = Alexanderson | first = Gerald L. | authorlink = Gerald L. Alexanderson | date = July 2014 | doi = 10.1090/S0273-0979-2014-01458-2 | issue = 3 | journal = Bulletin of the American Mathematical Society | pages = 463–467 | title = About the cover: Two theorems on geometric constructions | volume = 51}}.</ref>
The book is divided into two parts. In the first part, Mohr shows how to perform all of the constructions of [[Euclid]]'s [[Euclid's Elements|''Elements'']] using a compass alone. In the second part, he includes some other specific constructions, including some related to the mathematics of the [[sundial]].<ref>{{citation|title=An Impression of Mathematics in Denmark in the Period 1600–1800|first=Kirsti|last=Andersen|doi=10.1111/j.1600-0498.1980.tb00381.x|journal=Centaurus|volume=24|issue=1|year=1980|pages=316–334}}.</ref>
''Euclides Danicus'' languished in obscurity, possibly caused by its choice of language, until its rediscovery in 1928 in a bookshop in Copenhagen. Until then, the Mohr–Mascheroni theorem had been credited to [[Lorenzo Mascheroni]], who published a proof in 1797, independently of Mohr's work.<ref name="gla"/><ref name="nac"/> Soon after the rediscovery of Mohr's book, publications about it by [[Florian Cajori]] and [[Nathan Altshiller Court]] made its existence much more widely known.<ref name="gla"/><ref name="nac">{{citation | last = Court | first = N. A. | authorlink = Nathan Altshiller Court | doi = 10.1090/S0002-9904-1930-04976-9 | issue = 7 | journal = Bulletin of the American Mathematical Society | mr = 1561975 | page = 471 | title = Book Review: Euclides Danicus | volume = 36 | year = 1930}}.</ref><ref>{{citation | last = Cajori | first = Florian | authorlink = Florian Cajori | doi = 10.2307/2298942 | issue = 7 | journal = [[American Mathematical Monthly]] | mr = 1521787 | pages = 364–365 | title = A Forerunner of Mascheroni | volume = 36 | year = 1929}}.</ref> The Danish version was republished in facsimile in 1928 by the [[Royal Danish Academy of Sciences and Letters]], with a foreword by [[Johannes Hjelmslev]],<ref name="gla"/><ref name="nac"/><ref>{{citation | last = Menger | authorlink = Karl Menger | doi = 10.1007/BF01696783 | issue = 1 | journal = Monatshefte für Mathematik und Physik | language = German | mr = 1549801 | page = A3 | title = Literaturberichte: Euclides Danicus | volume = 37 | year = 1930}}.</ref><ref>{{citation|title=''Euclides danicus'', Amsterdam 1672 by Georg Mohr; Johannes Hjelmslev; ''Beiträge zur Lebensbeschreibung von Georg Mohr'' (1640-1697) by Johannes Hjelmslev|first=George|last=Sarton|authorlink=George Sarton|journal=[[Isis (journal)|Isis]]|volume=26|issue=1|year=1936|pages=167–170|jstor= 225067|doi=10.1086/347140}}.</ref> and a [[German language|German]] translation was published in 1929.<ref name="gla"/>
Only eight copies of the original publication of the book are known to survive. In 2005, one of these original copies was sold at auction, to [[Fry's Electronics]], for what [[Gerald L. Alexanderson]] calls a "ridiculously low price": US$13,000.<ref name="gla"/>
==References== {{reflist}}
Wikicommons has a copy of the original: https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Georg_Mohr%27s_Euclides_Danicus.pdf
==Further reading== *{{citation | last = Zühlke | first = P. | journal = Mathematisch-Physikalische Semesterberichte | mr = 0082435 | pages = 118–119 | title = Auf den Spuren des ''Euclides Danicus'' | volume = 5 | year = 1956}}.

{{Use British English|date=May 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2017}} {{Infobox non-profit | name = European Microscopy Society | image = | type = [[Professional Organisation]] and [[Charitable organization|Registered Charity]] | founded_date = September 1976 as European Societies of Electron Microscopy, current form September 1998{{cite web|title=History|url=http://www.eurmicsoc.org/en/organisation/ems-documentation/history/|website=www.eurmicsoc.org|accessdate=15 May 2017|language=en}} | tax_id = | registration_id = | founder = | location = | coordinates = | origins = European Societies of Electron Microscopy | key_people = President Dr Josef Zweck
Secretary Virginie Serin{{cite web|title=2016-2020 Board|url=http://www.eurmicsoc.org/en/organisation/executive-board/new/|website=www.eurmicsoc.org|accessdate=15 May 2017|language=en}} | area_served = Europe, Worldwide | product = | mission = ''to promote the use and the quality of advanced microscopy in all its aspects in Europe , with particular reference to developments in instrumentation and methodology and novel applications of all types of microscopy.''{{cite web|title=Mission Statement|url=http://www.eurmicsoc.org/en/organisation/ems-documentation/mission-statement/|website=www.eurmicsoc.org|accessdate=15 May 2017|language=en}}{{cite web|last1=Physics|first1=Institute of|title=European Microscopy Society|url=https://www.iop.org/about/international/involvement/page_41336.html|website=[[Institute of Physics]]|accessdate=15 May 2017}} | focus = | method = | revenue = €47,322.84{{cite journal|title=European Microscopy Society - Yearbook 2016|journal=www.eurmicsoc.org|date=15 February 2017|volume=2016|pages=3, 8-9, 52-53|url=http://www.eurmicsoc.org/en/organisation/ems-documentation/yearbook/|accessdate=17 June 2017|publisher=Manufacture d'Histoires Deux-Ponts|location=[[Bresson, Isère]]|language=en|issn=1609-1191}} | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = 5800 | subsid = | owner = | non-profit_slogan = | former name = | homepage = {{URL|http://www.eurmicsoc.org}} | dissolved = | footnotes = }} The '''European Microscopy Society''' is an international [[learned society]] which represents the field of [[microscopy]] in [[Europe]]. It was founded in 1998 following the disbanding of the ''Committee of European Societies of Electron Microscopy'' (which was founded in 1976) as a union of national microscopical societies. The society acts as a regional committee of the [[International Federation of Societies for Microscopy]]. ==Member societies== Listed below are the bodies which are members of the EMS. All those listed have reciprocal membership agreements.{{cite web|title=National and regional societies|url=http://www.eurmicsoc.org/en/organisation/societies/|website=www.eurmicsoc.org|accessdate=15 May 2017|language=en}} The society has 52 corporate members (ECMA) and 37 individual members, with 28 member countries.{{cite web|title=European Microscopy Society - Yearbook Profile|url=https://www.uia.org/s/or/en/1100038465|website=[[Union of International Associations]]|accessdate=15 May 2017|language=en}} ===National bodies=== *[[Armenian Electron Microscopy Society]] (AEMS) *[[Austrian Society for Electron Microscopy]] (ASEM) *[[Belgian Society for Microscopy]] (BSM) *[[Croatian Microscopy Society]] (CMS) *[[Czechoslovak Microscopy Society]] (CSMS) *[[Dutch Society for Microscopy]] (NVvM) *[[Institute of Physics|Electron Microscopy and Analysis Group]] ([[Institute of Physics]]) (EMAG){{cite web|last1=Physics|first1=Institute of|title=Electron Microscopy and Analysis Group|url=https://www.iop.org/activity/groups/subject/emag/|website=[[Institute of Physics]]|accessdate=16 May 2017}} *[[French Microscopy Society]] (SFµ) *[[German Society for Electron Microscopy]] (DGE) *[[Hellenic Microscopy Society]] (HMS) *[[Hungarian Society for Microscopy]] (HSM) *[[Israel Society for Microscopy]] (ISM) *[[Italian Society of Microscopical Sciences]] (SISM) *[[Microscopical Society of Ireland]] (MSI) *[[Nordic Microscopy Society]] (SCANDEM){{cite web|last1=Paavolainen|first1=Lassi|title=About the Society|url=http://www.scandem.org/the-society/about-the-society|website=[[Nordic Microscopy Society]].|accessdate=15 May 2017|language=en-gb}} *[[Polish Society for Microscopy]] (PTMi) *[[Portuguese Society for Microscopy]] (SPMicros) *[[Romanian Electron Microscopy Society]] (REMS) *[[Royal Microscopical Society]] (RMS){{cite web|title=Membership Benefits|url=http://www.rms.org.uk/membership/membership-benefits.html|website=[[Royal Microscopical Society]]|accessdate=15 May 2017}} *[[Serbian Society for Microscopy]] (SSM) *[[Slovene Society for Microscopy]] (SDM) *[[Spanish Society for Microscopy]] (SME) *[[Swiss Society for Optics and Microscopy]] (SSOM) *[[Turkish Society for Electron Microscopy]] (TEMD) ===Other societies=== *[[Bulgarian National Committee for Electron Microscopy]] *[[European Microbeam Analysis Society]] (EMAS) *[[Greek Society of Electron Microscopy]] *[[Institute of Physics]] *[[Latvian Society for Electron Microscopy]] *[[Rumanian National Committee for Electron Microscopy]] *[[Russian Academy of Sciences]] *[[Scottish Microscopy Group]] (SMG) ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{technical|date=December 2011}} In [[physics]], '''fractionalization''' is the phenomenon whereby the [[quasiparticle]]s of a system cannot be constructed as combinations of its elementary constituents. One of the earliest and most prominent examples is the [[fractional quantum Hall effect]], where the constituent particles are [[electrons]] but the quasiparticles carry fractions of the electron charge.<ref> {{cite web |date=24 October 1997 |title=Fractional charge carriers discovered |url=http://physicsworld.com/cws/article/news/3393 |website=[[Physics World]] |accessdate=2010-02-08 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Martin J, Ilani S, Verdene B, Smet J, Umansky V, Mahalu D, Schuh D, Abstreiter G, Yacoby A |title=Localization of fractionally charged quasi-particles |journal=Science |volume=305 |issue=5686 |pages=980–3 |year=2004 |pmid=15310895 |doi=10.1126/science.1099950|bibcode=2004Sci...305..980M }}</ref> Fractionalization can be understood as [[deconfinement]] of quasiparticles that together are viewed as comprising the elementary constituents. In the case of [[spin–charge separation]], for example, the electron can be viewed as a bound state of a '[[spinon]]' and a '[[chargon]]', which under certain conditions can become free to move separately.
== History == Quantized Hall conductance was discovered in 1980, related to the electron charge. Laughlin proposed a fluid of fractional charges in 1983, to explain the fractional quantum Hall effect seen in 1982, for which he shared the 1998 Physics Nobel Prize. In 1997, experiments directly observed an electric current of one-third charge. The one-fifth charge was seen in 1999 and various odd fractions have since been detected.
Disordered magnetic materials were later shown to form interesting spin phases. Spin fractionalization was seen in spin ices in 2009 and spin liquids in 2012.
Fractional charges continue to be an active topic in condensed matter physics. Studies of these quantum phases impact understanding of superconductivity, and insulators with surface transport for [[topological quantum computer]]s.
== Physics == Many-body effects in complicated condensed materials lead to emergent properties that can be described as quasiparticles existing in the substance. Electron behavior in solids can be considered as quasi-particle magnons, excitons, holes, and charges with different effective mass. Spinons, chargons, and anyons cannot be considered elementary particle combinations. Different quantum statistics have been seen; Anyons wavefunctions gain a continuous phase in exchange:<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Viewpoint: Liberating anyons from two dimensions|date = Jan 2010|journal = Physics|accessdate = |doi = 10.1103/Physics.3.7|pmid = |bibcode = 2010PhyOJ...3....7S |volume=3|pages = 7|last1 = Stern|first1 = Ady|last2 = Levin|first2 = Michael}}</ref>
<math>P(|\Psi_1\rangle|\Psi_2\rangle) = e^{i \theta}|\Psi_2\rangle|\Psi_1\rangle</math>
It has been realized many insulators have a conducting surface of 2D quantum electron gas states.
== Systems == [[Soliton|Solitons]] in 1D, such as [[polyacetylene]], lead to half charges.<ref>{{cite book|author1=R.A. Bertlmann|author2=A. Zeilinger|title=Quantum (Un)speakables: From Bell to Quantum Information|date=2002-07-27|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=978-3-540-42756-8|pages=389–91}}</ref> Spin-charge separation into spinons and holons was detected in electrons in 1D SrCuO<sub>2</sub>.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Distinct spinon and holon dispersions in photoemission spectral functions from one-dimensional SrCuO2|date = 21 May 2006|journal = Nature Physics|accessdate = |doi = 10.1038/nphys316|pmid = |bibcode = 2006NatPh...2..397K |volume=2 |issue = 6|pages=397–401|last1 = Kim|first1 = B. J|last2 = Koh|first2 = H|last3 = Rotenberg|first3 = E|last4 = Oh|first4 = S. -J|last5 = Eisaki|first5 = H|last6 = Motoyama|first6 = N|last7 = Uchida|first7 = S|last8 = Tohyama|first8 = T|last9 = Maekawa|first9 = S|last10 = Shen|first10 = Z. -X|last11 = Kim|first11 = C}}</ref> [[Quantum wire|Quantum wires]] with fractional phase behavior have been studied.
Spin liquids with fractional spin excitations occur in frustrated magnetic crystals, like ZnCu<sub>3</sub>(OH)<sub>6</sub>Cl<sub>2 </sub>([[herbertsmithite]]), and in α-RuCl<sub>3</sub>.<ref>{{cite journal |first1=A. |last1=Banerjee |first2=C. A. |last2=Bridges |first3=J.-Q. |last3=Yan |display-authors=etal |title=Proximate Kitaev quantum spin liquid behaviour in a honeycomb magnet |journal=[[Nature Materials]] |doi=10.1038/nmat4604 |subscription=yes |date=4 April 2016 |volume=15 |issue=7 |pages=733–740 |pmid=27043779|arxiv=1504.08037 |bibcode=2016NatMa..15..733B }}<!--|accessdate=4 April 2016--></ref> Spin ice in Dy2Ti2O7 and Ho2Ti2O has fractionalized spin freedom, leading to deconfined magnetic monopoles.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1146/annurev-conmatphys-020911-125058 |author1=C. Castelnovo |author2=R. Moessner |author3=S. Sondhi |title=Spin Ice, Fractionalization, and Topological Order |journal=Annual Review of Condensed Matter Physics |volume=3 |issue=2012 |year=2012 |pages=35–55|arxiv=1112.3793}} </ref> They should be contrasted with quasiparticles such as [[magnon]]s and [[Cooper pair]]s, which have [[Quantum numbers#Elementary particles|quantum numbers]] that are combinations of the constituents. The most celebrated may be quantum Hall systems, occurring at high magnetic fields in 2D electron gas materials such as GaAs heterostructures. Electrons combined with magnetic flux vortices carry current. Graphene exhibits charge fractionalization.
Attempts have been made to extend fractional behavior to 3D systems. Surface states in [[topological insulator]]s of various compounds (e.g. [[tellurium]] alloys, [[antimony]]), and pure metal ([[bismuth]]) crystals<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Signatures of Electron Fractionalization in Ultraquantum Bismuth|year = 1729|journal = Science|accessdate = |doi = 10.1126/science.1146509|pmid = 17702909|arxiv = 0802.1993 |bibcode = 2007Sci...317.1729B |volume=317 |issue = 5845|pages=1729–1731 | last1 = Behnia | first1 = K | last2 = Balicas | first2 = L | last3 = Kopelevich | first3 = Y}}</ref> have been explored for fractionalization signatures.
==Notes== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Theoretical physics]] [[Category:Condensed matter physics]]

revision.text:
{{about|the Australian photographer and adventurer|the U.S. congressional candidate|United States House of Representatives elections in North Carolina, 2010#District 13{{!}}United States House of Representatives elections in North Carolina, 2010|the Australian rugby league footballer of the 1930s, and 1940s|Frank Hurley (rugby league)}} {{Use British English|date=August 2011}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2011}} {{Infobox writer | name = Frank Hurley | image = FrankHurley.png | alt = | image_size = 220px | caption = Frank Hurley, photographed c.1914 | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1885|10|15}} | birth_place = Glebe, Sydney, Australia | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1962|1|16|1885|10|15}} | death_place = [[Sydney]], Australia | nationality = Australian | known_for = | occupation = Photographer | notableworks = ''[[Shackleton's Argonauts|Shackleton's Argonauts : A Saga of Antarctic Icepacks]]'' | awards = [[Children's Book of the Year Award: Older Readers]] 1948 | years_active = 1908–1948 }}
'''James Francis Hurley''', [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]] (15 October 1885 – 16 January 1962) was an Australian photographer and adventurer. He participated in a number of expeditions to [[Antarctica]] and served as an official photographer with Australian forces during both [[world wars]].
His artistic style produced many memorable images. He also used staged scenes, composites and photographic manipulation.
==Biography== Hurley was the third of five children to parents Edward and Margaret Hurley and was raised in [[Glebe, New South Wales|Glebe, a suburb of Sydney, Australia]].<ref>McGregor (2004) p 8</ref> He ran away from home at the age of 13 to work on the Lithgow steel mill, returning home two years later to study at the local technical school and attend science lectures at the University of Sydney. When he was 17 he bought his first camera, a 15-shilling [[Eastman Kodak|Kodak]] [[Brownie (camera)|Box Brownie]] which he paid for at the rate of a shilling per week. He taught himself photography and set himself up in the postcard business, where he gained a reputation for putting himself in danger in order to produce stunning images, including placing himself in front of an oncoming train to capture it on film.
Hurley married Antoinette Rosalind Leighton on 11 April 1918.<ref name="Hurley-ADB"/> The couple had four children: three daughters and one son.<ref name="Hurley-ADB"/>
While living on [[Collaroy Plateau]], ([[Warringah]] LGA), Frank became involved with ABC radio. He was a frequent storyteller on the perennial children's program ''The Argonauts''.{{citation needed|date=February 2015}} He enjoyed even more a degree of commercial success by publishing his photos on advertising calendars, postcards and tourist booklets.{{citation needed|date=February 2015}}
His most successful book was ''Australia: A Camera Study ''published in 1955 and reprinted three times.{{citation needed|date=February 2015}}
He engaged in aerial photography with Brud Rees on his Piper Cub float plane. He travelled extensively throughout Australia commissioned on various photographic assignments.<ref>McGregor (2004) p. 406-409</ref>
==Antarctic expeditions== Of his lifetime, Frank Hurley spent more than four years in Antarctica.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Frank Hurley’s Antarctica.|last = Ennis|first = Helen|publisher = National Library of Australia.|year = 2010|isbn = |location = Australia|pages = 2}}</ref> At the age of 23, in 1908, Hurley learned that Australian explorer [[Douglas Mawson]] was planning an expedition to Antarctica; fellow Sydney-sider [[Henri Mallard]] in 1911, recommended Hurley for the position of official photographer to Mawson's [[Australasian Antarctic Expedition]], ahead of himself.<ref>while Hurley records his approach to Mawson differently in his memoir, the fact of this introduction via Mallard was established by David P. Millar in Millar (1984).</ref> Hurley asserts in his biography that he then cornered Mawson as he was making his way to their interview on a train, using the advantage to talk his way into the job.<ref>[[Jack Cato]] in his obituary explains Hurley's motivation and enthusiasm; 'We were both fired with the Spirit of Adventure; we were both happy in the knowledge that the camera was the key that would open that Magic Door.' Cato, Jack, 'For the Late Frank Hurley, Three Tributes', ''Australian Popular Photography'', March 1962.</ref> Mawson was persuaded, while Mallard, who was the manager of Harringtons (a local Kodak franchise) to which Hurley was in debt, provided photographic equipment. The Expedition departed in 1911, returning in 1914. On his return, he edited and released a documentary, ''Home of the Blizzard'', using his footage from the expedition.<ref name="Hurley-ADB"/>
Hurley was also the official photographer on [[Ernest Shackleton]]'s [[Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition]] which set out in 1914 and was marooned until August 1916; Hurley produced many pioneering colour images of the Expedition using the then-popular [[Paget process]] of colour photography. He photographed in [[South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands|South Georgia]] in 1917. He later compiled his records into the documentary film ''South'' in 1919. His footage was also used in the 2001 [[IMAX]] film ''[[Shackleton's Antarctic Adventure]]''. He returned to the Antarctic in 1929 and 1931 on Mawson's British Australian (and) New Zealand Antarctic Research Expeditions ([[BANZARE]]).
<gallery mode="packed" class="center" widths="160px" heights="160px"> File:Wreck of the 'Gratitude', Macquarie Island, 1911.jpg|''Wreck of the 'Gratitude', Macquarie Island, 1911'' File:Endurance in Antarctica, 1915 Hurley a090007.jpg|''Endurance in Antarctica, 1915'' Image:Endurance trapped in pack ice.jpg|Frank Hurley, ''HMS Endurance trapped in Antarctic pack ice'', 1915, [[National Library of Australia]] in Canberra File:Glimpse of the Endurance Shackleton Expedition 1914-17 Hurley a090018.jpg|The ''Endurance'' File:Endurance Final Sinking.jpg|''Endurance Final Sinking'' File:Antarctica wind Mawson Hurley.jpg|Mawson leaning against the wind File:Elephant island party.jpg|The Elephant Island party File:British Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition, 1914-1917.jpg|Hurley with a cinematograph in South Georgia, Antarctica File:Frank Hurley's business card.jpg|Business card, 1910 </gallery>
==Wartime photography== In 1917, Hurley joined the [[First Australian Imperial Force|Australian Imperial Force]] (AIF) as an honorary [[Captain (land)|captain]] and captured many stunning battlefield scenes during the [[Third Battle of Ypres]]. In keeping with his adventurous spirit, he took considerable risks to photograph his subjects, also producing many rare panoramic and colour photographs of the conflict. Hurley kept a diary in 1917-1918 chronicling his time as a war photographer.<ref>{{cite web|title=Series 03: Frank Hurley diaries and related papers, 21 August 1917 – 13 August 1918, kept while official photographer to the Australian Imperial Force|url=http://acmssearch.sl.nsw.gov.au/search/itemDetailPaged.cgi?itemID=422460|website=Catalogue|publisher=State Library of NSW|accessdate=14 July 2014}}</ref> In it he describes his commitment "to illustrate to the public the things our fellows do and how war is conducted", as well as his short-lived resignation in October 1917 when he was ordered not to produce composite images.<ref name="Transcript">{{cite web|url=http://acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/_transcript/2012/D14653/a2826.htm|title=Frank Hurley war diary, 21 August-28 October 1917|publisher=}}</ref> His period with the AIF ended in March 1918.
For the 1918 London exhibition ''Australian War Pictures and Photographs ''he employed composites for photomurals to convey drama of the war on a scale otherwise not possible using the technology available. This brought Hurley into conflict with the AIF on the grounds that montage diminished documentary value.<ref>for an account of the conflict between Hurley and the war correspondent Charles Bean, see Gough, Paul. "‘Exactitude is truth’: representing the British military through commissioned artworks". Journal of War and Culture Studies Volume: 1 | Issue: 3 December 2008 Page(s): 341–356 ({{ISSN|1752-6272}}), and also the excellent discussion of this, and Hurley's use of montage in some of his Antarctic imagery, in McGregor, Alasdair (2004) ''Frank Hurley: a photographer's life''.'' ''Camberwell:Viking/Penguin</ref> [[Charles Bean]], official war historian, labelled Hurley's composite images "fake".<ref name="Hurley-ADB"/>
Hurley also served as a war photographer during [[World War II]].

F. Hurley, August 1917- August 1918|url=http://acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=423850|work=Catalogue|publisher=State Library of NSW|accessdate=7 November 2013}}</ref> File:Supports going up after battle to relieve the front trenches, note the three observation balloons above the bright cloud (3007981750).jpg|Supports going up after battle to relieve the front trenches, note the three observation balloons above the bright cloud File:A trench in the low flat country near La Bassee Ville (3007144955).jpg|A trench in the low flat country near La Bassee Ville File:Chateauwood.jpg|Chateau Wood, [[Ypres]], 1917 by Frank Hurley File:Australian soldiers September 1917.JPG|Australian soldiers in action, September 1917 File:World War I soldiers in dugout.JPG|Soldiers in dugout File:An Australian Light Horseman.jpg|An Australian Light Horseman File:A flight of bombing planes.jpg|1st Australian Flying Corps, Palestine </gallery>
==Movie photography== [[File:Captain Frank Hurley (20663756393).jpg|thumb|right|Hurley, on the right, discusses photographic opportunities for the forthcoming Battle of Bardia with an officer of the Australian 6th Division, Egypt, 1940]] Hurley also used a [[movie camera]] to record a range of experiences including the Antarctic expeditions, the building of the [[Sydney Harbour Bridge]], and war in the Middle East during World War II. The camera was a [[Debrie Parvo]] L 35mm hand-crank camera made in France. This camera is now in the collection of the [[National Museum of Australia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nma.gov.au/collections/frank_hurleys_movie_camera/|title=Frank Hurley's movie camera - National Museum of Australia|publisher=}}</ref>
==Film career== Hurley made several documentaries throughout his career, most notably ''[[Pearls and Savages]]'' (1921). He wrote and directed several dramatic feature films, including ''[[Jungle Woman (1926 film)|Jungle Woman]]'' (1926) and ''[[The Hound of the Deep]]'' (1926). He also worked as cinematographer for [[Cinesound Productions]] where his best known film credits include ''[[The Squatter's Daughter (1933 film)|The Squatter's Daughter]]'' (1933), ''[[The Silence of Dean Maitland]]'' (1934) and ''[[Grandad Rudd]]'' (1935). His 1941 documentary short ''[[Sagebrush and Silver]]'' was nominated for an [[Academy Award]] at the [[14th Academy Awards]] for [[Academy Award for Best Live Action Short Film|Best Short Subject (One-Reel)]].<ref name="Oscars1942">{{Cite web|url=http://www.oscars.org/oscars/ceremonies/1942 |title=The 14th Academy Awards (1942) Nominees and Winners |accessdate=2013-06-25 |work=oscars.org}}</ref>
== In Collections == [[File:A radiant turret lit by the midsummer midnight sun.jpg|thumb|"A radiant turret lit by the midsummer midnight sun", 1912 photo by Hurley held by [[State Library of New South Wales]].]] Photographs by Hurley of the Antarctic are held by a number of institutions. Notable collections include the [[Australian War Memorial]], [[Canberra]], [[National Library of Australia]], [[Canberra]], [[Scott Polar Research Institute]], Cambridge, [[Royal Geographical Society]], London, [[State Records of South Australia]], and the [[South Australian Museum]], Adelaide.
'''National Library of Australia''' *''Frank Hurley Negative Collection'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.pic-an11546686|title=Hurley negative collection [picture]|publisher=}}</ref> 1910–1962 The collection contains 10,999 glass negatives, gelatin negatives, colour transparencies, lantern slides, and stereographs that have been fully catalogued and digitised.
The collection covers photographs of Hurley's trips to Antarctica; as official photographer during World War I 1914–1918; later travels in the Middle East and Egypt; as official photographer during World War II 1939–1945; Papua and New Guinea; Australian scenery, industries and social life and customs.
Related photographic prints can be found in the ''Hurley Collection of Photographic Prints''. *''Hurley collection of photographic prints'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.pic-an24539066|title=Hurley collection of photographic prints [picture]|publisher=}}</ref> 1910–1962 The collection contains 1000 photographic prints. 44 prints have been catalogued and digitised. *''B.A.N.Z. Antarctic Research Expedition 1929–31, photographs'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.pic-an13751629|title=B.A.N.Z. Antarctic Research Expedition 1929-31, photographs [picture]|publisher=}}</ref> 1929–1931 This album contains 60 gelatin silver photographs by Hurley, all of which have been catalogued and digitised. *''Photograph album of Papua and the Torres Strait'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.pic-vn3201344|title=Photograph album of Papua and the Torres Strait [picture]|publisher=}}</ref> The collection contains 259 photographic prints, all of which have been catalogued and digitised.
'''State Records of South Australia'''
As part of South Australia's Centenary celebration in 1936, Frank Hurley was commissioned to produce images of South Australia for inclusion in an illustrated souvenir booklet.<ref>[[State Records of South Australia]], GRG 7/29 File 13/1935.</ref> The resulting glass plate negatives are held as part of a series of glass plate negatives produced by or for the South Australian Government for publicity or other purposes.<ref>See [[State Records of South Australia]], GRG 35/342/1 Glass plate and other negatives - Photolithographic Branch, Department of Lands, units 181 - 186.</ref>
At this time, Hurley was also commissioned to produce a couple of promotional films for the South Australian Government, ''Oasis''<ref>See [[State Records of South Australia]], GRG 7/77 Motion picture films - Tourist Bureau, Film 10 ''Oasis''</ref> and ''Here is Paradise''.<ref>See [[State Records of South Australia]], GRG 7/77 Motion picture films - Tourist Bureau, Film 30 ''Here is Paradise''</ref>
